channel.title: Array of JTextFields. Adding/referring

item.title: Array of JTextFields. Adding/referring
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“ixia, post:14, topic:536093”]Why would you want use an array to hold each field? You would still need to initialize.

Using arrays [size=8pt](I think this is what you meant)[/size]

JTextField[] field; field[0] = new JTextField(); field[1] = new JTextField(); field[3] = new JTextField();
[size=8pt](if that even works)[/size]

Apposed to:

JTextField field1 = new JTextField(); JTextField field2 = new JTextField(); JTextField field3 = new JTextField();

Are you looking to do some silly optimization?[/quote]not really, i think he was just exploring the boundaries of the keith von schnellenberger readability heuristics…

Read full topic

[size=8pt](if that even works)[/size]

item.title: Array of JTextFields. Adding/referring
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

idk the exact context but why not just loop through the components of the panel and if its a JTextField change it as desired.

    for (Component c : this.getComponents()) {
        if (c instanceof JTextField) {
            ((JTextField) c).setText("PANIC! Randomised Block!!");
        }
    }

Read full topic

item.title: Array of JTextFields. Adding/referring
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:11, topic:536093”][quote author=ohokay link=topic=654902.msg4386027#msg4386027 date=1385589114]

Totally doable. I would probably use an ArrayList.

[code]
ArrayList textFields = new ArrayList();

for (int i = 0; i < 20; i++) {
textFiends.add(new JTextField(args));
}[/code]
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/ArrayList.html

Seems kinda silly what you’re trying to do, but ArrayList may help you out.

I know I can do that, but they create new text fields, and don’t change the values of the text fields I already have declared
[/quote]
You’re asking if it’s possible to take your 50 arbitrary variables and automatically put them into an array without explicitly adding each one - to which the simple answer is no. If you can initialise them in the loop like pwnd suggested then do that, otherwise you’ll just have to write the code to add each one.[/quote]

Yeah that was it, thanks

Read full topic

item.title: Array of JTextFields. Adding/referring
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“ohokay, post:8, topic:536093”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=654902.msg4385996#msg4385996 date=1385574471]
Totally doable. I would probably use an ArrayList.

[code]
ArrayList textFields = new ArrayList();

for (int i = 0; i < 20; i++) {
textFiends.add(new JTextField(args));
}[/code]
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/ArrayList.html

Seems kinda silly what you’re trying to do, but ArrayList may help you out.
[/quote]

I know I can do that, but they create new text fields, and don’t change the values of the text fields I already have declared :|[/quote]
You’re asking if it’s possible to take your 50 arbitrary variables and automatically put them into an array without explicitly adding each one - to which the simple answer is no. If you can initialise them in the loop like pwnd suggested then do that, otherwise you’ll just have to write the code to add each one.

Read full topic

item.title: Array of JTextFields. Adding/referring
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:9, topic:536093”][quote author=ohokay link=topic=654902.msg4386027#msg4386027 date=1385589114]

Totally doable. I would probably use an ArrayList.

[code]
ArrayList textFields = new ArrayList();

for (int i = 0; i < 20; i++) {
textFiends.add(new JTextField(args));
}[/code]
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/ArrayList.html

Seems kinda silly what you’re trying to do, but ArrayList may help you out.

I know I can do that, but they create new text fields, and don’t change the values of the text fields I already have declared
[/quote]You are missing the point though, the code I gave you and the code Pwnd gave you are supposed to be where you first create the jtextareas. You remove these:

JTextField jTextField1; JTextField jTextField2; JTextField jTextField3;[/quote]

Yeah I noticed, my question was whether I could use the ones I’ve already made. I guess not so thanks for all the help.

Read full topic

item.title: Array of JTextFields. Adding/referring
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:5, topic:536093”][quote author=ohokay link=topic=654902.msg4385848#msg4385848 date=1385509806]

Im not quite sure what exactly this is for, but if I understand you correctly some sort of map or set might work fine for what you want.

Like if I have 10 fields, instead of changing them all manually, like

jTextField1.setText("One");
jTextField2.setText("Two");
jTextField3.setText("Three");

I could just refer to the array, using a loop and change all the values that way.

Am I able to add them to the map or array using a loop? Because I could have like 10-20 boxes.

		JTextField[][] boxes = new JTextField[2][5];
		JTextField jTextField1;
		//..
		JTextField jTextField10;
		
		for (int i = 0; i < boxes[0].length; i++ ) {
			boxes[0][i] = ? //first 5
		}

How would I add them all to the array like this?

[/quote]It really depends on what sort of information you need to put in the boxes… maybe you could tell us more what the program is for and there might be a better solution. If you are just referencing them by index,

JTextField[] boxes = new JTextField[X]; //how many do you need?
for(int i = 0; i < boxes.length; i++) {
  boxes[i] = new JTextField(); //How are you going to know what to put in these?
}

And then you can just use boxes[index].setText() and such… is that what you mean?[/quote]

boxes[index].setText()

This is what I want to be able to do at the end yes, I can refer to a specific box by index, or I could change the values of all the boxes using a loop.

But my question is can I add existing fields to this array, without adding them manually, because there could be up to 20 boxes, and it will look a mess if it looks like the code below.

JTextField jTextField1;
JTextField jTextField2;
JTextField jTextField3;

boxes[0] = jTextField1;
boxes[1] = jTextField2;
boxes[2] = jTextField3;

Here’s an example of what I tried

       int i = 0;
	for (int j = 0; j < boxes.length; j++) {
            boxes[j] = new javax.swing.JTextField("jTextField".concat(Integer.toString(++i)));
        }

But this creates a new field, instead of using the existing ones I have declared. I’m trying to refer to the variables in the program

Sorry if my explanation is bad. I don’t even think this is possible :palm: but perhaps there is another way

Read full topic

JTextField[] boxes = new JTextField[X]; //how many do you need?

  boxes[i] = new JTextField(); //How are you going to know what to put in these?
}

And then you can just use boxes[index].setText() and such… is that what you mean?

item.title: Array of JTextFields. Adding/referring
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

I’m looking to add a bunch of JTextFields to an array, that I can use to change the value of that box later on in the program. My current efforts have failed and I’m not sure whether I’m going about it the correct way.

Once all the fields are in the array, I can refer to each individual field and change the value. Sometimes it will be specific fields, sometimes I will need to change all of them so this is why I’m looking to do this.

private javax.swing.JTextField jTextField1;
private javax.swing.JTextField jTextField2;
private javax.swing.JTextField jTextField3;
private javax.swing.JTextField jTextField4;
private javax.swing.JTextField jTextField5;

public Object[][] boxes = new Object[2][5];

for (int j = 0; j < boxes.length; j++) {
            javax.swing.JTextField jtf = new javax.swing.JTextField((String)boxes[0][j]);
            jtf.setText("TRUE");
}

Using this I can add the boxes to the array, but then I struggle with how to refer to them as actual variables in order to change the value of the box.

I’ve also tried using a JTextField array instead of object, but I can’t seem to find out how to add them all in a loop.

Any help is appreciated.

Read full topic
